values: "Last week, the horror genre lost one of its greats with the death of actor/producer Karl. Hardman only made one film, but he had one of the all-time great movie roles: playing Harry Cooper in George A. Romero's Night of the Living Dead. Hardman was the hard-ass counterpart to Duane Jones' more reasonable Ben, and memorably met his end at the hands of his real-life daughter Krya Schon, in one of the most shocking moments in horror film history. Hardman not only co-starred in Night, he also produced it and became the film's main historian and caretaker, providing a wealth of materials for the film's DVD and laserdisc special editions." I know this may sound silly but this really makes me sad. http://www.ghoulnextdoor.com/blog/2007/09/my-dad.html http://synapsefilms.blogspot.com/2007/09/another-dear-friend-has-passed-away.html

Of course the song doesn't hurt either.

[In the Hamdan decision,] Justice Thomas refers to Justice Stevens' "unfamiliarity with the realities of warfare"; but Stevens served in the U.S. Navy from 1942 to 1945, during World War II. Thomas's official bio, by contrast, contains no experience of military service.

Sources have confirmed to CBS4 News that conservative talk show host Rush Limbaugh has been detained at Palm Beach International Airport for the possible possession of illegal prescription drugs Monday evening.

Limbaugh was returning on a flight from the Dominican Republic when officials found the drugs, among them Viagra.

Limbaugh entered a plea deal back in April in a previous case where his charge of fraud to conceal information to obtain prescriptions was dropped under the condition he continue undergoing treatment for addiction.

Limbaugh had admitted to being addicted to pain killers on his radio program and had entered a rehabilitation program prior to that arrest.

...I was watching The Colbert Report and he was interviewing congressman Lynn Westmoreland, who had proposed a bill in the House to have the Ten Commandments posted in Court Houses and other government builings. Well,Colbert asked him to list the Ten Commandments. Fair request, right? Or you would think so-o-o-o, ri-i-i-ight? Well, this right-wing conservative nimrod couldn't list all of them, he maybe got three or four right. And he couldn't even put in bible talk. It was don't lie, don't steal,...So-o-o-o-o, I guess that's why they want to have The Ten Commandments posted everywhere because they can't seem to remember them. So, I am going to pick up some laminated cards with The Ten Commandments printed on them and I will pass them out to all the dumbasses who think The Ten Commandments need to be posted anywhere outside of a church.

Thus Endeth The Sermon

I have a real love hate relationship with the Speilberg. One of the things that I like...actually I would go so far as to say LOVE...about this movie is the fact that Francois Truffuat is in it. He dies less than 10 years later. If you don't know who he is then I would highly recommend you get off your ass and go check him out(definitely his films from the 60's, Shoot The Piano Player, Jules and Jim!) His first full-length was 400 Blows which was a French film shot in 59 or 60. He and Godard(and don't get me going about Godard, uhm, Breathless!) were at the fore-front of the french new wave. His character is acually based perhaps in a very loose baseness on Jacque Vallee, a French UFOlgist. Also I had forgotten how evocative the music was in Close E. To me it envokes the feeling of Disney(spefically Pinocchio) and I mean that in a good way because in a lot of ways I am not a big fan of Disney being as I was born and raised here in Mouseville. Also once I figured out how much John Williams ripped off from other composers I have a hard being impressed with him. lets post this and see how it goes! Se ya!
